ygData.subject: collision efficiency problem
ygData.msgSnippet: i have discovered a bug that may affect how collision efficiencies for three-body and falloff reactions are read from the input file for some reaction

From: David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...>
Subject: collision efficiency problem
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

i have discovered a bug that may affect how collision efficiencies for 
three-body and falloff reactions are read from the input file for some 
reaction mechanisms. Collision efficiencies are specified in strings 
like this:

          efficiencies = " AR:0.7  C2H6:3  CH4:2  CO:1.5  CO2:2  H2:2  
H2O:6 "

Unfortunately, in the code that parses the <name>:<value> pairs, the 
string representing the numerical value for each species was being 
truncated to a length equal to the number of species in the list.  In 
this example, there is no problem, since there are 7 species listed, an 
all of the values have less than 7 characters. On the other hand, a 
specification like

          efficiencies = " AR:0.83  H2:2.4  H2O:15.4 "

has problems, since there are only 3 species but two of the value 
strings have four characters.  The efficiencies will be read in as if 
the string were "AR:0.8 H2:2.4 H2O:15."

This problem DOES NOT affect GRI-Mech 3.0 (gri30.cti or gri30.xml), but 
does affect h2o2.cti.  Other mechanisms not included with Cantera may 
or may not be affected - you should check any mechanisms you use.

This problem has been fixed in the CVS repository on the 
Prerelease_1_6_0_branch branch.  If you are compiling from the source 
code (whatever version you have), you can fix it yourself. Open file 
Cantera/src/ctml.cpp, and in function "getPairs" at line 384, change 
"v.size()" to  "v[i].size()". That is, change the line

             val.push_back(v[i].substr(icolon+1, v.size()));

to read

             val.push_back(v[i].substr(icolon+1, v[i].size()));

and recompile/install.

If you are using Cantera from a binary installation, a work-around is 
to simply make sure that the efficiencies string has enough entries to 
avoid the truncation problem.  For example, adding one more species 
(with value set to the default of 1.0) fixes the problem in the second 
string above:

          efficiencies = " AR:0.83  H2:2.4  H2O:15.4 H:1"


I am sorry this problem was not caught much earlier, and hope it hasn't 
caused too many problems.  It affects the flame1 demo, which uses 
h2o2.cti, but does not affect the flame2 demo, which uses gri30.cti. 
The changes in the solution for flame1 are minor, but the peak 
temperature changes by a couple of degrees.

Dave
